problem: In the interior of triangle $P_1P_2P_3$ a point $P$ is given. Let $Q_1,Q_2,Q_3$ be the intersections of $PP_1, PP_2,PP_3$ with the opposing edges of triangle $P_1P_2P_3$. Prove that among the ratios $\frac{PP_1}{PQ_1},\frac{PP_2}{PQ_2},\frac{PP_3}{PQ_3}$ there exists one not larger than $2$ and one not smaller than $2$.
solution: Let $K_1=[P_2PP_3], K_2=[P_3PP_1],$ and $K_3=[P_1PP_2].$ Note that by same base in triangles $P_2PP_3$ and $P_2P_1P_3,$ \[\frac{P_1P}{PQ_1}+1=\frac{P_1Q_1}{PQ_1}=\frac{[P_2P_1P_3]}{[P_2PP_3]}=\frac{K_1+K_2+K_3}{K_1}.\] Thus, \[\frac{P_1P}{PQ_1}=\frac{K_2+K_3}{K_1}\]\[\frac{P_2P}{PQ_2}=\frac{K_1+K_3}{K_2}\]\[\frac{P_3P}{PQ_3}=\frac{K_1+K_2}{K_3}.\] Without loss of generality, assume $K_1\leq K_2\leq K_3.$ Hence, \[\frac{P_1P}{PQ_1}=\frac{K_2+K_3}{K_1}\geq \frac{K_1+K_1}{K_1}=2\] and \[\frac{P_3P}{PQ_3}=\frac{K_1+K_2}{K+3}\leq \frac{K_3+K_3}{K_3}=2,\] as desired.
